query.esql:
from logs-corelight.conn-*
| limit 10000
| where observer.vendor == "Corelight" and event.dataset == "conn" and observer.hostname is not null and network.protocol == "dns"
| stats count(), count_distinct(source.ip), values(destination.geo.country_name) , values(conn.local_resp) by destination.ip
| eval `values(destination.geo.country_name)` = case(`values(destination.geo.country_name)` is null, "Unknown",
`values(destination.geo.country_name)`)
| eval Internal = case(
    `values(conn.local_resp)` == true, "yes", "no")
| rename destination.ip as Destination, `count()` as `# of Queries`, `count_distinct(source.ip)` as `# of Unique Clients`, `values(destination.geo.country_name)` as Country
| sort `# of Queries` DESC, `# of Unique Clients` ASC
| keep Destination, `# of Queries`,`# of Unique Clients`,`Country`, Internal
| stats count()
| rename `count()` as `Responding DNS Servers`

from logs-corelight.conn-*
| limit 10000
| where observer.vendor == "Corelight" and event.dataset == "conn" and observer.hostname is not null and network.protocol == "dns"
| stats count(), count_distinct(source.ip), values(destination.geo.country_name) , values(conn.local_resp) by destination.ip
| eval `values(destination.geo.country_name)` = case(`values(destination.geo.country_name)` is null, "Unknown",
`values(destination.geo.country_name)`)
| eval Internal = case(
    `values(conn.local_resp)` == true, "yes", "no")
| rename destination.ip as Destination, `count()` as `# of Queries`, `count_distinct(source.ip)` as `# of Unique Clients`, `values(destination.geo.country_name)` as Country
| sort `# of Queries` DESC, `# of Unique Clients` ASC
| keep Destination, `# of Queries`,`# of Unique Clients`,`Country`, Internal
| stats count()
| rename `count()` as `Responding DNS Servers`

panelsJSON.title: DNS Servers actively responding to queries [Logs Corelight]

params.markdown: DNS servers actively responding in the network are key to secure operations, translating domain names to IP addresses and directing traffic. It also logs the number of queries and unique clients interacting with the DNS servers, offering insights into possible rogue DNS servers and detecting patterns that may suggest data exfiltration attempts.

panelsJSON.title: DNS Servers actively responding to queries [Logs Corelight]

query.esql:
from logs-corelight.dns-*
| limit 10000
| where observer.vendor == "Corelight" and event.dataset == "dns" and observer.hostname is not null and dns.response_code == "NXDOMAIN"
| stats count() by source.ip, destination.ip, dns.question.name, dns.flags.rejected
| rename source.ip as Source, destination.ip as Responder, dns.question.name as Query, dns.flags.rejected as query_rejected, `count()` as Count
|eval `Rejected?` = case(query_rejected == true, "Yes", "No")
| keep Source, Responder, Query, `Rejected?`, Count
| stats sum(Count)
| rename `sum(Count)` as `NXDOMAIN Responses`

from logs-corelight.dns-*
| limit 10000
| where observer.vendor == "Corelight" and event.dataset == "dns" and observer.hostname is not null and dns.response_code == "NXDOMAIN"
| stats count() by source.ip, destination.ip, dns.question.name, dns.flags.rejected
| rename source.ip as Source, destination.ip as Responder, dns.question.name as Query, dns.flags.rejected as query_rejected, `count()` as Count
|eval `Rejected?` = case(query_rejected == true, "Yes", "No")
| keep Source, Responder, Query, `Rejected?`, Count
| stats sum(Count)
| rename `sum(Count)` as `NXDOMAIN Responses`

params.markdown: High rates of DNS NXDOMAIN responses might suggest misconfigured domains, typographical errors in network requests, or malicious activities such as DNS reconnaissance. Close examination is advised to correct configurations or identify security incidents. Review DNS logs for patterns, validate domain configurations, and check endpoint security for signs of malware.

Unusual DNS query types can indicate misconfigurations, experimental features, or potential security threats like data exfiltration or tunneling. Analysts should scrutinize such queries for anomalies and address identified risks to safeguard network security.

query.esql:
from logs-corelight.dns-*
| limit 10000
| where observer.vendor == "Corelight" and event.dataset == "dns" and observer.hostname is not null and dns.response_code == "NXDOMAIN"
| stats count() by source.ip, destination.ip, dns.question.name, dns.flags.rejected
| rename source.ip as Source, destination.ip as Responder, dns.question.name as Query, dns.flags.rejected as query_rejected, `count()` as Count
|eval `Rejected?` = case(query_rejected == true, "Yes", "No")
| sort Count desc
| keep Source, Responder, Query, `Rejected?`, Count

from logs-corelight.dns-*
| limit 10000
| where observer.vendor == "Corelight" and event.dataset == "dns" and observer.hostname is not null and dns.response_code == "NXDOMAIN"
| stats count() by source.ip, destination.ip, dns.question.name, dns.flags.rejected
| rename source.ip as Source, destination.ip as Responder, dns.question.name as Query, dns.flags.rejected as query_rejected, `count()` as Count
|eval `Rejected?` = case(query_rejected == true, "Yes", "No")
| sort Count desc
| keep Source, Responder, Query, `Rejected?`, Count

attributes.title: Table Source & Responder & Query & Rejected? & Count

panelsJSON.title: Network Evidence for NXDOMAIN Responses [Logs Corelight]

params.markdown: Failed DNS queries may point to misconfigurations, outdated systems, or security threats such as network infiltration or DNS poisoning. Analysts should investigate the sources and patterns of these failures to identify and remediate underlying causes, thereby ensuring network integrity and security.

query.esql:
from logs-corelight.dns-*
| limit 10000
| where observer.vendor == "Corelight" and event.dataset == "dns" and observer.hostname is not null
| stats avg_rtt = avg(dns.rtt) by dns.question.name,destination.ip
| where avg_rtt > 0.015
| eval avg_rtt = to_string(round(avg_rtt*1000, 2))
| rename dns.question.name as Query, destination.ip as Responder, avg_rtt as `Avg. Response Time (ms)`
| stats count(Query) 
| rename `count(Query)` as `Monitoring DNS Query Response Times > 15ms`

from logs-corelight.dns-*
| limit 10000
| where observer.vendor == "Corelight" and event.dataset == "dns" and observer.hostname is not null
| stats avg_rtt = avg(dns.rtt) by dns.question.name,destination.ip
| where avg_rtt > 0.015
| eval avg_rtt = to_string(round(avg_rtt*1000, 2))
| rename dns.question.name as Query, destination.ip as Responder, avg_rtt as `Avg. Response Time (ms)`
| stats count(Query) 
| rename `count(Query)` as `Monitoring DNS Query Response Times > 15ms`

panelsJSON.title: Monitoring DNS Query Response Times > 15ms [Logs Corelight]

params.markdown: Long DNS query response times may indicate network congestion, server performance issues, or potential security threats. Timely analysis is crucial for maintaining optimal network performance and security. Investigate extended response times by examining server configurations, network traffic, and potential external attacks.

panelsJSON.title: Monitoring Query Types by AVG time [Logs Corelight]
DNS Query Volume Over Time [Logs Corelight]

params.markdown: Monitor total DNS-related network traffic in MB/GB. Sudden spikes or unusual patterns could signal configuration errors, compromised devices making excessive queries, or potential data exfiltration attempts.
